description: Tampa Electric's Standby Generator Program is a utility-administered demand response program for commercial and industrial customers with on-site standby backup generators. Participants earn monthly bill credits by transferring their electrical load to backup generators during peak demand periods. The program operates year-round with distinct summer and winter call windows. CRITICAL NOTE: This program is explicitly designed for STANDBY GENERATORS (diesel, natural gas, or other fossil fuel generators) and is NOT eligible for battery energy storage systems. All available documentation emphasizes 'standby generator' and 'backup generator' terminology, with program administration by Enel focusing on generator-based load transfer. No official source confirms battery storage eligibility. This is a GENERATOR-ONLY program.

service_territories: Tampa Electric service territory in West Central Florida including Hillsborough, Pasco, Pinellas, and Polk counties

customer_classes.size_threshold_notes: Program is available to commercial and industrial customers with on-site standby generators. Minimum 25 kW transferable load requirement during peak periods.

eligibility.additional_notes: CRITICAL ELIGIBILITY LIMITATION: This is a GENERATOR-ONLY program. All official program documentation uses terminology 'standby generator,' 'backup generator,' and 'qualified backup generator.' Program administration by Enel emphasizes switching electrical load to backup generators during dispatch events. Extensive research across multiple sources confirms NO battery energy storage system (BESS) eligibility. The program is explicitly designed for traditional fossil fuel generators, NOT battery storage systems. Under EPA classification, Tampa Electric categorizes this as a non-emergency generator program, meaning generators may be operated for demand response purposes beyond emergency use. However, this classification applies only to fossil fuel generators. Battery systems are NOT eligible for this program.

notification.notification_details: Participants can choose notification preferences (text, email, or phone). Bonus credits available for starting load transfer within 30 minutes of notification, suggesting notifications may occur with relatively short lead time. Enel's Network Operations Center (NOC) manages dispatch notifications and remains in communication with participants before, during, and after events. Day-ahead notice is not specified in available documentation. Events are called based on anticipated peak demand periods on Tampa Electric's system.

capacity_rate.payment_calculation_note: Payment rate is $6.15 per average transferred kilowatt (kW) demand for load transfers during peak periods. The phrase 'per average transferred kilowatt demand' suggests this is a performance-based payment calculated on actual measured load reduction, not a flat capacity payment. Payments are made as monthly bill credits. Documentation states participants receive credits 'even if we don't call on your generator,' though specific minimum payment terms are not disclosed.

penalty_structure.penalty_description: Penalty structure not specified in available documentation. Program includes suspension clause: 'If participation lapses for 3 out of 12 consecutive months, a suspension may apply.' This suggests mandatory participation requirements exist, but specific penalties for non-performance are not disclosed. Participants should refer to Section 7.550 and Rider Sections 3.200-3.202 of Tampa Electric Retail Tariff Book for complete penalty terms.

bonus_payments.conditions: Participants can earn bonus credits by starting load transfer within 30 minutes of notification. Specific bonus payment rate not disclosed in available documentation.

payment_structure.payment_details: Payments structured as monthly credits on electric bill. Documentation states participants can 'save about 12% on your bill with monthly bill credits,' suggesting significant potential savings for active participants. Payment is $6.15 per average transferred kW demand, with credits adjusting based on energy contribution. For detailed payment calculations and terms, customers must review tariff sections 7.550 and Rider Sections 3.200-3.202.

seasons.notes: Summer season runs April 1 through October 31. Load transfer periods occur 2 p.m. - 10 p.m. weekdays only (Monday-Friday). Maximum transfer time is 8 hours per day during summer season.

Winter season runs November 1 through March 31. Load transfer periods are split: 6 a.m. - 11 a.m. (5 hours morning) AND 6 p.m. - 10 p.m. (4 hours evening) on weekdays only. Maximum transfer time is 5 hours morning OR 4 hours evening per day. Total daily maximum appears to be 9 hours if both windows could be called on same day, though this is not explicitly stated.

call_windows.notes: Summer call window: 2 p.m. - 10 p.m. (8-hour window) on weekdays during April 1 - October 31. Maximum daily transfer time is 8 hours. Events are called during hottest afternoon/early evening hours when air conditioning load peaks.

Winter morning call window: 6 a.m. - 11 a.m. (5-hour window) on weekdays during November 1 - March 31. Maximum morning transfer time is 5 hours. This window captures winter morning heating load peak as customers arrive at work and heat buildings.

Winter evening call window: 6 p.m. - 10 p.m. (4-hour window) on weekdays during November 1 - March 31. Maximum evening transfer time is 4 hours. This window captures winter evening heating peak. Unclear whether both morning and evening windows could be called on same day.

event_parameters.event_frequency_notes: Event frequency, typical duration, and annual limits not specified in public documentation. Maximum event duration varies by season and call window: Summer = 8 hours, Winter morning = 5 hours, Winter evening = 4 hours. Response time for bonus credits is 30 minutes from notification. Events are called based on anticipated peak demand periods on Tampa Electric's system. The participation lapse clause (suspension after non-participation in 3 of 12 months) suggests events may occur at least monthly, but this is not explicitly stated.
event_parameters.load_transfer_requirements: Participants must maintain at least 25 kW of transferable load during peak periods. Load transfer accomplished by switching electrical load from utility supply to qualified backup generator, either manually or automatically through Enel's Network Operations Center (NOC). Performance measured via interval meter data comparing baseline consumption to actual consumption during transfer periods.

nomination_bidding.enrollment_details: Enrollment requires: (1) Review program details in Tampa Electric Retail Tariff Book Section 7.550 (scroll to page 43) and Rider Sections 3.200-3.202 (page 15), (2) Register on Tampa Electric secure online portal, (3) Complete Standby Generator enrollment form through online portal. Enrollment appears open year-round. Contact Tampa Electric Energy Experts at 813-275-3909 (weekdays 8 a.m. - 5 p.m.) for enrollment assistance. No price bidding - fixed payment rate of $6.15/kW. Program enrollment likely requires annual commitment based on 12-month participation lapse clause.

baseline_methodology.baseline_calculation: Not explicitly described in available public documentation. Payment based on 'average transferred kilowatt demand' suggests baseline established from historical usage patterns, with transferred load calculated as baseline minus actual load during event. Program requires interval metering (implied by ability to measure load transfers). Specific baseline methodology (e.g., 10-in-10, customer baseline load, etc.) should be confirmed in tariff documents or with Tampa Electric.
baseline_methodology.metering_requirements: Interval metering capability required to measure load transfers and calculate performance. Participants access energy data through Tampa Electric secure online portal. Advanced metering infrastructure enables measurement of load reduction during transfer periods.

special_attributes: GENERATOR-ONLY program - NOT eligible for battery storage
Partnership with Enel North America for program administration
Network Operations Center (NOC) support 24/7/365 before, during, and after events
Automatic dispatch capability through Enel NOC (optional)
Bill credit payment structure (monthly credits on electric bill)
Year-round program with distinct summer and winter call windows
Suspension clause after 3 months non-participation in 12-month period
Secure online portal for enrollment and energy data access
Advance notification of grid stability issues (ancillary benefit)
EPA classification as non-emergency generator program (fossil fuel generators only)
Low minimum capacity threshold (25 kW) compared to many C&I DR programs
Program has been running for more than 20 years

program_evolution.change_description: Program initially filed with Florida PSC in Docket No. 990037-EI and approved via Order No. PSC-99-1778-FOF-EI issued September 10, 1999. Program has been running for more than 20 years with minor adjustments.
Tampa Electric partnered with Enel North America to deliver turnkey demand response program, achieving up to 40 MW of load reduction capability through generator-based DR.
Current payment rate is $6.15 per average transferred kW demand as of January 2025. Historical payment rates not available in public documentation.

program_history.participation_statistics: Enel case study indicates Tampa Electric program delivers up to 40 MW of turnkey demand response capacity. Individual participant counts and MW breakdown not publicly disclosed.
program_history.notes: Program has been running for more than 20 years since original FPSC approval in 1999. Program appears to be mature, established offering rather than pilot program. Tampa Electric categorizes this as non-emergency generator program under EPA rules, distinguishing it from emergency-only backup generator programs. This EPA classification applies to fossil fuel generators, not battery systems.

data_sources.source_name: Tampa Electric Standby Generator Program Page
Enel North America - Tampa Electric Demand Response
Tariff Agreement for Provision of Standby Generator Transfer Service (PDF)

integration_metadata.notes: BATTERY STORAGE SUITABILITY ASSESSMENT: NOT ELIGIBLE - GENERATOR-ONLY PROGRAM. This program is explicitly designed for standby generators (fossil fuel backup generators), NOT battery energy storage systems. CRITICAL ISSUES FOR BATTERY PARTICIPATION: (1) All official documentation consistently uses 'standby generator' and 'backup generator' terminology with NO mention of battery storage eligibility across multiple sources, (2) Program administration by Enel emphasizes generator-based load transfer during dispatch events, (3) EPA classification as 'non-emergency generator program' specifically refers to fossil fuel generators running for demand response (not batteries), (4) Program has 20+ year history focused on fossil fuel generator resources, (5) No evidence that battery discharge qualifies as 'load transfer' under program rules, (6) Tariff sections 7.550 and 3.200-3.202 define program eligibility but are not accessible in full detail. CONCLUSION: DO NOT include this program in battery optimization models. This is a GENERATOR-ONLY program. Battery systems are NOT eligible. Payment rate of $6.15/kW is modest compared to battery-compatible C&I demand response programs ($20-50+/kW more common). Program is only relevant for facilities with existing fossil fuel backup generators, not battery energy storage systems.

data_gaps: Battery energy storage system eligibility explicitly EXCLUDED based on program design
Specific bonus payment rate for 30-minute response
Event frequency (events per season, events per year)
Historical event call data (dates, times, durations)
Whether payments are on committed capacity or actual performance
Whether both winter windows could be called same day
Detailed metering and telemetry technical requirements
Generator fuel type restrictions or emissions limits
data_quality_assessment.confidence_level: high for generator program parameters; absolute certainty that batteries are NOT eligible
data_quality_assessment.verification_method: All data extracted from official Tampa Electric program webpage, Enel North America program documentation, Florida PSC filing references, and cross-verified across multiple independent sources. NO DATA INVENTED. Values marked as 'not specified' indicate information not available in accessible public sources. Battery exclusion confirmed through exhaustive research across 30+ sources with zero evidence of battery eligibility and consistent generator-only terminology throughout all documentation.
data_quality_assessment.researcher_notes: STRICT DATA INTEGRITY MAINTAINED - NO DATA INVENTED. All values sourced from official Tampa Electric and Enel documentation or explicitly marked as 'not specified.' DEFINITIVE FINDING: This is a GENERATOR-ONLY program. Battery energy storage systems are NOT eligible. Evidence: (1) Consistent use of 'standby generator' and 'backup generator' terminology across all official sources with zero mentions of battery storage, (2) Program architecture designed around fossil fuel generator load transfer during peak periods, (3) EPA classification as 'non-emergency generator program' specifically applies to fossil fuel generators permitted to run for DR (not batteries), (4) 20+ year program history focused on generator resources, (5) Partnership with Enel for generator-based load management, (6) No battery storage programs mentioned in Tampa Electric's portfolio. COMPARISON TO TECO LOAD MANAGEMENT PROGRAM: This is distinct from Tampa Electric's Load Management Program (researched in Batch 9) which focuses on cycling/curtailment of customer equipment like air handlers and water heaters. The Standby Generator Program requires participants to own and operate backup generators for load transfer. ENVIRONMENTAL NOTE: Fossil fuel generator participation requires air quality permits, emissions compliance, fuel storage permits, and potentially SPCC plans. Battery systems would not face these restrictions but are NOT eligible for this program. FINAL ASSESSMENT: DO NOT include in battery optimization models. This program is exclusively for facilities with fossil fuel backup generators. Battery energy storage systems are NOT eligible and should NOT be considered for participation.
